column1: == History ==
Potomac is a European spelling of Patawomeck
column2: the Algonquian name of a Native American village on its southern bank. Native Americans had different names for different parts of the river
column3: calling the river above Great Falls Cohongarooton
column4: meaning "honking geese" and "Patawomke" below the Falls
column5: meaning "river of swans". The spelling of the name has taken many forms over the years from "Patawomeck" (as on Captain John Smith's map) to "Patomake"
column6: "Patowmack"
column7: and numerous other variations in the 18th century and now "Potomac". The river's name was officially decided upon as "Potomac" by the Board on Geographic Names in 1931.

column1: The river itself is at least 3.5 million years old
column2: likely extending back ten to twenty million years before present when the Atlantic Ocean lowered and exposed coastal sediments along the fall line. This included the area at Great Falls
column3: which eroded into its present form during recent glaciation periods.

column1: == Legal issues ==
For 400 years Maryland and Virginia have disputed control of the Potomac and its North Branch
column2: since both states' original colonial charters grant the entire river rather than half of it as is normally the case with boundary rivers. In its first state constitution adopted in 1776
column3: Virginia ceded its claim to the entire river but reserved free use of it
column4: an act disputed by Maryland. Both states acceded to the 1765 Mount Vernon Compact and the 1877 Black-Jenkins Award which granted Maryland the river bank-to-bank from the low water mark on the Virginia side
column5: while permitting Virginia full riparian rights short of obstructing navigation.

column1: From 1957 to 1996
column2: the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) routinely issued permits applied for by Virginia entities concerning use of the Potomac.  However
column3: in 1996 the MDE denied a permit submitted by the Fairfax County Water Authority to build a water intake 725 feet (220 m) offshore
column4: citing potential harm to Maryland's interests by an increase in Virginia sprawl caused by the project. After years of failed appeals within the Maryland government's appeal processes
column5: in 2000 Virginia took the case to the Supreme Court of the United States
column6: which exercises original jurisdiction in cases between two states. Maryland claimed Virginia lost its riparian rights by acquiescing to MDE's permit process for 63 years (MDE began its permit process in 1933). A Special Master appointed by the Supreme Court to investigate recommended the case be settled in favor of Virginia
column7: citing the language in the 1785 Compact and the 1877 Award. On December 9
column9: the Court agreed in a 7–2 decision.

column1: The original charters are silent as to which branch from the upper Potomac serves as the boundary
column2: but this was settled by the 1785 Compact. When West Virginia seceded from Virginia in 1863
column3: the question of West Virginia's succession in title to the lands between the branches of the river was raised
column4: as well as title to the river itself. Claims by Maryland to West Virginia land north of the South Branch (all of Mineral and Grant Counties and parts of Hampshire
column5: Hardy
column6: Tucker and Pendleton Counties) and by West Virginia to the Potomac's high-water mark were rejected by the Supreme Court in two separate decisions in 1910.

column1: === Mammals ===
Early European colonists who settled along the Potomac found a diversity of large and small mammals living in the dense forests nearby. Bison
column2: elk
column3: wolves ( gray and red) and panthers (cougars) were still present at that time
column4: but had been hunted to extirpation by the middle of the 19th century.  Among the denizens of the Potomac's banks

column6: while small populations of minks and martens survived into the 20th century in some secluded areas.
